question: A vehicle commences motion from rest under constant acceleration of $5  \text{m/s}^2$ for $10  \text{s}$ using the kinematic relation $v = u + at$ with $u = 0  \text{m/s}$; employing the resultant scalar quantity as the initial velocity $u$ for the subsequent phase, calculate the stopping distance when decelerating constantly at $a = -5  \text{m/s}^2$ to rest via $v^2 = u^2 + 2as$ where $v = 0  \text{m/s}$, ensuring all motion adheres strictly to constant acceleration constraints without external assumptions.
subject: physics
constant_ev: Assume initial velocity u = 0 m/s when applying the kinematic equation v = u + at
Assume constant acceleration when applying the kinematic equation v = u + at
Use acceleration a = 5 m/s² in the velocity calculation using v = u + at
Use time t = 10 s in the velocity calculation using v = u + at
Assume constant acceleration when applying the kinematic equation v² = u² + 2as
Assume final velocity v = 0 m/s when calculating stopping distance using v² = u² + 2as
Use deceleration a = -5 m/s² in the stopping distance calculation using v² = u² + 2as
derived_ev: The kinematic equation v = u + at is valid under constant acceleration conditions
The calculation (5 m/s²)(10 s) results in 50 m/s
The velocity of the car after accelerating for 10 seconds is 50 m/s
The relevant kinematic equation for calculating stopping distance under constant acceleration conditions is v² = u² + 2as
The time required to stop is 10 seconds
The average velocity during deceleration is 25 m/s
The stopping distance calculated using v² = u² + 2as is 250.0 meters
The stopping distance of the car is 250 meters

tier1_result.reasoning: The solver's answer (250 m) matches the expected 250 because v = u + at gives 50 m/s after acceleration and v² = u² + 2as with u = 50 m/s and a = -5 m/s² yields s = 250 m. Units are consistent in SI, so the calculations are correct and the answers agree.
